<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 170, 200]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 207, 279, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 248, 590, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 313, 386, 329]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 343, 890, 403]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil. Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid. Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 890, 465]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 475, 555, 491]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 504, 764, 535]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer. Any rough working should be done in this booklet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 816, 91]]<|/det|> A pendulum is set in motion and timed. The time measured for 20 complete swings is <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 598, 121]]<|/det|> What is the time for one complete swing of the pendulum? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 132, 695, 149]]<|/det|> **A** 0.67s **B** 0.75s **C** 1.5s **D** 3.0s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 176, 96, 195]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 176, 900, 193]]<|/det|> Two stones of different weight fall at the same time from a table. Air resistance may be ignored. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 206, 346, 223]]<|/det|> What will happen and why? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 236, 885, 362]]<|/det|>
what will happenwhy
Aboth stones hit the floor at the same timeacceleration of free fall is constant
Bboth stones hit the floor at the same timethey fall at constant speed
Cthe heavier stone hits the floor firstacceleration increases with weight
Dthe heavier stone hits the floor firstspeed increases with weight
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 390, 96, 409]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 390, 664, 408]]<|/det|> The speed-time graph shown is for a bus travelling between stops. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 421, 607, 438]]<|/det|> Where on the graph is the acceleration of the bus greatest? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 448, 803, 628]]<|/det|>

<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 365, 920, 413]]<|/det|>
A dam across a lake is divided into two sections by a rock. Section X is longer than section Y but the two sections are otherwise identical. The water in the lake by the dam is the same depth everywhere. The diagram shows a view from above of the lake and the dam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 787, 146, 804]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 814, 141, 832]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 840, 524, 857]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 866, 141, 884]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 866, 561, 883]]<|/det|>
The pressure on X is less than the pressure on Y.

what an echo is caused bynature of sound waves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 804, 264, 820]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 515, 107, 533]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 515, 919, 548]]<|/det|> An electric oven is connected to the mains supply using insulated copper wires. The wires become very warm. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 560, 810, 577]]<|/det|> What can be done to prevent so much heat being produced in the connecting wires? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 588, 364, 605]]<|/det|> A Use thicker copper wires. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 615, 364, 631]]<|/det|> B Use thinner copper wires. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 642, 337, 657]]<|/det|> C Use thicker insulation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 668, 337, 683]]<|/det|> D Use thinner insulation.

time
/min		count-rate/
counts per min
0340
2180
4100
660
840
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 535, 920, 567]]<|/det|> The experiment is repeated by other students, who also measure the count-rate every two minutes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 578, 625, 594]]<|/det|> The half-life of the source is known to be exactly two minutes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 606, 747, 622]]<|/det|> Why is the measured count-rate **always** higher than half the previous value? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 634, 555, 650]]<|/det|> **A** Radioactive emissions occur randomly with time. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 661, 528, 677]]<|/det|> **B** The detector used is very close to the source. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 688, 472, 703]]<|/det|> **C** There is background radiation present. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 714, 446, 729]]<|/det|> **D** The radioactive source is decaying.
